results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 2
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and David Corke
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from Tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “The Anteater and the Turtle” - story by Nathanael Maralngura, artist Neville Jabangadi Poulson; “The old Dingo who had six wives” - story by Bill Middikari Jambidjimba, artist Harry Djagamara Nelson; “How the Kangaroo got his tail” - Story by Andrew Leku, artist Ralph Gumudul. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba”. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and David Corke

results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 1
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and David Corke
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “The thirsty Sandfrog” - story by Miriam Rose Wilson, artist Ralph Gumudul; “The Witchdoctor and the two giants” - story by Lionel Jabanangga James, artist David Gentian; “Why the Kangaroo hops” - story by Nugget Jabangadi James, artist Neville Jabangadi Poulson. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.

results.title: Aboriginal fibre crafts of Aurukun
results.brief_description: The traditional fibre crafts of the Aboriginal women of Aurukun are demonstrated by Annie Kalkeeyorta and Neeyum Yunkaporta, from the collection and spinning of the fibres through to the varieties of finished products. Narrated by Jane Harders.
results.description: The traditional fibre crafts of the Aboriginal women of Aurukun are demonstrated by Annie Kalkeeyorta and Neeyum Yunkaporta, from the collection and spinning of the fibres through to the varieties of finished products. Narrated by Jane Harders.

results.title: Aboriginal Family Education Centre: Alexandria 1972
results.brief_description: A record of the Van Leewin project’s Aboriginal Family Education Centre in Redfern, Sydney. Parents learn with their children, mothers record the children’s activities with video. Differences between black and white cultural values are articulated and clarified.
results.description: A record of the Van Leewin project’s Aboriginal Family Education Centre in Redfern, Sydney. Parents learn with their children, mothers record the children’s activities with video. Differences between black and white cultural values are articulated and clarified.

results.title: Ablutions
results.brief_description: Ablutions is an interactive journey where the user controls the fate of a character in a world that consumes technology. Through exploring the narrative the user partakes in the experience of cleansing the self from everyday technology and its commodities; questioning the nature of our identity. By doing this, freedom is redefined. Once cleansed, the character recovers the lost items, discovering their meaning and importance.

results.title: Abilene Paradox (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Janice M Reynolds, CRM Productions and Peter Jordon
results.brief_description: Deals with the management of agreement in organisations. Illustrates that mismanaged agreement is as dangerous to organisational effectiveness as excessive conflict because it can lead to inappropriate goals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Janice M Reynolds, CRM Productions and Peter Jordon

results.title: Abel Gance: Hier et Demain
results.brief_description:
In this documentary narrated by Abel Gance and directed by his former assistant (and filmmaker) Nelly Kaplan, the great director reminisces about his career which started in the silent era. With ‘Mater Dolorosa’ (1917) and especially ‘La dixieme symphonie’(1918), ‘J’accuse’ (1919) and ‘La roue’ (1921-23), Gance became a leading member of the French avant-garde. His work was characterised by dramatic excess (La dixieme symphonie), formal inventiveness (La roue), and technical innovation (split screens, complex camera movements, experiments with sound), all trends which find their apotheosis in ‘Napoleon vu par Abel Gance’ (1927), a five hour epic comparable to Griffith’s ‘The birth of a nation’ (1915) in its combination of reactionary ideology and formal brilliance.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The companion to French cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996.

Credits: Director, Nelly Kaplan ; music, Michel Magne.

results.title: A.S. Neill
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doubts and Certainties”.
An interview with A. S. Neil, headmaster of the pioneer school of Summerhill in Suffolk for fifty years. Here he discusses Hunkin and his belief that education must not be indoctrination and that the child’s emotions should be completely free.
